Graphical abstract The effect of Cu loading and Si content on catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method was investigated in ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) reaction. The Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with Cu loading of 2.49 wt.% shows superior NH3-SCR performance and hydrothermal stability due to the presence of more isolated Cu2+ species and the less amount of CuO species. What’s more, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with different Si content exhibit distinct NH3-SCR performance, though they contain similar Cu loading. The NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and EPR results indicate that the number of acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts rises with increasing Si content from 0.084 to 0.173, but decreases with the highest Si content of 0.204. Consequently, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst shows the best NH3-SCR performance. After hydrothermal treatment, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst exhibits excellent NO reduction efficiency which attributes to its stable framework and the most amount of acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions. Additionally, the NH3-SCR kinetic analysis over Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst was also performed and suggesting that Cu loading and Si content do not influence the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism. Keywords Cu-SAPO-18 Cu loading Si content NH3-SCR Hydrothermal stability 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) emissions from both stationary applications and mobile sources can cause severe environmental pollution and human health issues. To satisfy stringent emission standards, the abatement of NOx emissions is widely investigated. The selective catalytic reduction of NOx with NH3 (NH3-SCR) has been proven to be one of the most effective technologies for eliminating the NOx emissions [1,2]. Currently, copper-based zeolites have been extensively studied as NH3-SCR catalysts for after-treatment system of diesel engine [3,4]. Particularly, copper-based small pore sized zeolites with CHA structure, such as Cu-SSZ-13 and Cu-SAPO-34 have attracted substantial attention due to their outstanding NH3-SCR performance, high N2 selectivity and superior hydrothermal durability [5–8]. Recently, other potential small pore zeolites with the AEI structure (e.g., Cu-SSZ-39 and Cu-SAPO-18), which is a chabazite-related structure, also attract keen interest [9–11]. Moliner et al. [12] reported that Cu-SSZ-39 exhibited even better NH3-SCR activity and hydrothermal stability than commercial Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst. Cu-SAPO-18, which is an aluminosilicophosphate with AEI structure isomorphic to Cu-SSZ-39, also performs excellent deNOx activity and hydrothermal stability [10,13]. It allows that the Cu-AEI catalysts could be one of most attractive SCR catalysts in the automotive industry. It is well-known that the distribution of Cu plays an important role in NH3-SCR reaction over Cu-based zeolites. Indeed, the nature of Cu species could be directly affected by Cu loading. Wang et al. [14] stated that the amounts of isolated Cu2+ and CuO species of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst increased with the increase of Cu loading. Therefore, the low-temperature NH3-SCR activity increased as Cu loading increased. While, the high-temperature deNOx activity decreased with increasing the Cu content from 1.5 wt.% to 3.0 wt.%. Besides, Kim et al. [15] investigated the Cu-SSZ-13 with various Cu content, and suggested that the Cu-SSZ-13 catalyst with high Cu content exhibited poor hydrothermal stability due to the agglomeration of isolated Cu2+ species which could give rise to the collapse of zeolite framework during hydrothermal treatment. In consequence, the Cu loading is vital to the Cu-zeolite in NH3-SCR. What’s more, for aluminosilicophosphate molecular sieves, the SAPO framework is generated by the substitution of P in the AlPO4 structure with Si, resulting in the formation of protons. Meanwhile, the extra-framework cationic species could be stabilized due to the introduction of negative charges into zeolite structure. On the contrary, the multiple substitutions of Al and P with Si lead to the formation of Si islands which can hardly stabilize the extra-framework cationic species [10,14,16]. Therefore, the Si content could affect the number of acid sites and the nature of Cu species which strongly influence the catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-zeolite catalysts [15,17–20]. For example, Yu et al. [21] investigated the implication of the acid content on NH3-SCR activity over Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst by adjusting the Si content. It is demonstrated that increasing the acid content could enhance the deNOx performance. Besides, as suggested by Wang et al. [20], the Si content not only affects the acid content but also the Cu exchange degree of Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst. And it is found that the Cu-SAPO-34 catalyst with higher Si content, which has more content of acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions in a certain range of (Si + P)/Al, exhibited high NH3-SCR performance. While the SAPO framework with fairly high Si content is more prone to be damaged during severe hydrothermal condition due to the large presence of Si islands [22]. Therefore, it can be concluded that the nature of Cu species and Si content play a significant role in NH3-SCR reaction. However, few studies are reported on the effect of the nature of copper species and Si content on NH3-SCR activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. Thus, in this investigation, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with various Cu loadings and silicon contents were prepared and the catalytic activities were examined before and after hydrothermal treatment. Moreover, XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, 29Si MAS NMR, NH3-TPD, EPR, H2-TPR and NH3-SCR kinetic tests were used to understand the relationships among the nature of Cu species, the Si content and the NH3-SCR performance of Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation and hydrothermal aging treatment The N, N-diisopropylethylamine (C8H19N, DIPEA) template was used for synthesis of the SAPO-18 zeolite with different Si contents [23]. The composition of the gel in the molar ratio was x SiO2:1.0 Al2O3:0.9 P2O5:2.0 DIPEA:45 H2O, where x differed to obtain samples with different silicon contents. Firstly, the mixture of pseudoboehmite, H3PO4, SiO2 and H2O was stirred for 3 h. Then, the C8H19N was added to this mixture solution and stirred until homogeneous. Finally, the homogeneous solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and hydrothermally synthesized at 180 °C for 4 days. The resulting products were filtered in vacuum and washed with deionized water, then the solids were dried at 100 ℃ for 12 h and calcined in air at 600 ℃ for 5 h to remove structure directing agent. Finally, the H-SAPO-18 supports with different Si contents were obtained. The Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method [11]. The H-SAPO-18 support was firstly ion exchanged with NH4 + by using a NH4NO3 solution at 80 ℃ for 6 h. Then, the copper nitrate solution was instilment to the NH4-SAPO-18 at ambient temperature followed by ultrasonic treatment. Finally, the samples were dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined in air at 600 °C for 5 h. The catalysts with different Cu loading and Si content were denoted as Cuy-SAPO-18 and Cu-SAPO-18(x), the corresponding catalysts are shown in Table 1 . Where x and y represent the Si molar composition and Cu loading, respectively. The monolithic SCR catalyst was prepared to test the deNOx activity. In a typical coating progress, 0.5 g of catalyst powders was put in deionized water to obtain the slurries, then the slurries were coated on honeycomb cordierites (cylinder, diameter: 11 mm, length: 22 mm, bulk: 2.1 cm3, 400 cell cm−2) until the channel was filled with liquid, then dried at 100 ℃ for 2 h. By strictly controlling the frequency of coating and the concentration of the slurries, finally, about 143 g/L of catalyst powders on the cordierites was obtained. To explore the hydrothermal stability of the catalysts, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts were hydrothermally disposed in a flow rate of 1000 cm3/min air with 10% H2O at 750 ℃ for 12 h. The resulting catalysts were designated as Cuy-SAPO-18-750 ℃ and Cu-SAPO-18(x)-750 ℃, where x and y represent the Si molar composition and Cu loading, respectively. 2.2 NH3-SCR performance measurement The SCR activity was tested in a fixed-bed flow reactor (VDRT-200SCR, produced by Quzhou Vodo instrument Co. Ltd., China.) with a stainless-steel tubular reactor using monolithic SCR catalyst. The temperature was measured by a type K thermocouple inserted directly into the center of the monolithic catalyst. The monolithic catalyst was activated in N2 at 600 ℃ for 30 min, and then 1000 ppm of NO, 1100 ppm of NH3, 5% O2, 10% water vapor with balance N2 was introduced into the reactor. The total gas flow rate was maintained at 1045 cm3 min−1 and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was 30,000 h−1. The water vapor was generated by a syringe pump (TYD01-01, LEAD FLUID) and then injected into the fixed-bed reactor through flowing N2. To avoid the error caused by NH3, the excessive NH3 was eliminated by an NH3 trap containing phosphoric acid solution which was installed in front of the analyzer. The flue gas analyzer (FGA-4100) was used to measure the concentration of NO in the product gases. The conversion of NO was calculated according to the following equation: N O C o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = NO inlet - NO outlet NO inlet × 100 % 2.3 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on PANalytical X’Pert Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ ranging from 5° to 40°. The specific surface area of the different catalysts was measured at 77.3 K by using the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) method (V-Sorb 2800 P), and the micropore volume of catalysts were calculated by t-Plot method. Prior to the measurement, the catalysts were degassed at 150 °C under vacuum for 4 h. Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) was performed on Micrometrics AutoChem 2920II chemisorption analyzer. Prior to the desorption, 50 mg sample was pretreated at 550 °C in Ar for 1 h and subsequently cooled to 100 °C. Ammonia adsorption was conducted in a flow of NH3/Ar (30 ml/min) at 100 °C for 45 min. Finally, the sample was heated from 100 to 550 °C at a ramping rate of 10 °C/min. 29Si MAS NMR experiments were performed on Agilent 600 MHz spectrometer at a resonance frequency of 119.13 MHz. 29Si MAS NMR spectra were recorded with spinning rate of 7 kHz with a 6 m m probe at room temperature. The Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectra of samples were measured on a Bruker A300 spectrometer at 150 K to decrease the mobility of Cu2+ ions. 10 mg of sample was loaded in the quartz tube for the EPR measurements. The field was swept from 165 to 465 mT and modulated at 100 kHz with 5 G amplitude. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was also carried out on Micrometrics AutoChem 2920II chemisorption analyzer. Prior to reduction, 50 mg sample was pretreated at 550 °C in Ar for 1 h and then cooled to ambient temperature. The sample was reduced from room temperature to 940 °C in a flow of H2/Ar (10 ml/min) at a ramping rate of 10 ℃/min. 2.4 Kinetics test The NH3-SCR kinetic tests were measured in fixed-bed flow reactor using monolithic SCR catalyst. 100 mg catalysts were coated on honeycomb cordierites (cylinder, diameter: 11 mm, length: 22 mm, bulk: 2.1 cm3, 400 cell cm−2) and then packed in the flow reactor. Before the kinetic experiments, the monolithic catalysts were pretreated in N2 at 600 °C for 30 min, and the inlet gas composition consisted of 1000 ppm of NO, 1100 ppm of NH3, 5% O2, 10% water vapor with balance N2. The total gas flow rate and the gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) were controlled 1045 cm3 min−1 and 30,000 h−1, respectively. The kinetic steady state measurements were obtained in the temperature region from 140 to 190 ℃. The exhaust gases were measured by flue gas analyzer (FGA-4100), the NH3-SCR reaction rates can be calculated as: rate mol NO g catal -1 S -1 = X NO % × F NO L NO min -1 m catal g ×60 S min -1 ]×22.4 L mol -1 mol NO g catal -1 S -1 where XNO is the NO conversion, FNO is the flow rate of NO, mcatal is the mass of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of copper loading 3.1.1 XRD The XRD profiles of H-SAPO-18, fresh and aged Cuy-SAPO-18 catalysts are plotted in Fig. 1 . The H-SAPO-18 and fresh Cuy-SAPO-18 catalysts show the AEI structure [10], suggesting that the introduction of Cu does not change the SAPO-18 structure. There are no CuO species peaks appearing with the rise in Cu content indicating that CuO species is dispersed evenly or CuO particle size is too small to be detected [24]. After hydrothermal aging treatment at 750 °C for 12 h, the peaks intensity of aged Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts decreases compared to the fresh catalysts, revealing the collapse of zeolite framework to some extent. Particularly, the peak intensity of Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst decreases obviously, and a new tridimite (SiO2) dense phase at 21.3° is observed [25], indicating that Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst suffers more serious structural damage than other catalysts. 3.1.2 H2-TPR and EPR To investigate the nature of Cu species in various Cuy-SAPO-18 catalysts, the H2-TPR is measured. Fig. 2 represents the H2-TPR profiles of fresh and aged catalysts. For the fresh catalysts, the TPR curves from 140 ℃ to 940 ℃ can be divided into five peaks. The peak A at 210–240 ℃ is assigned to the reduction of low stable isolated Cu2+ ions to Cu+ ions and the peak C at about 350 ℃ is attributed to the reduction of high stable isolated Cu2+ ions to Cu+ ions [26–28]. The peak B in the range of 280–300 °C represents the reduction of CuO to Cu° in a one-step process [26,29]. The peak D around 440 °C comes from the reduction of Cu+ to Cu°, and the peak E at 550–580 °C may be attributed to the reduction of stable Cu+ to Cu° [11], where the formation of the Cu+ species includes the reduction of isolated Cu2+ ions and the initial Cu+ existed in the framework of Cu-SAPO-18 [30]. Hence, the amount of the original Cu+ species existing in the framework of the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts was calculated by subtracting the merged region of peak A or peak B from the merged region of peak D or peak E [20,30]. According to the H2-TPR deconvolution, the quantitative result of copper species is summarized in Table 2 . For the fresh catalysts, the amount of isolated Cu2+ ions increases as the Cu content increases. Furthermore, EPR is a useful technique to quantitatively confirm the amount of isolated Cu2+ species due to the silent behavior of CuO, and Cu+ species. As shown in Fig. S1, the EPR peaks area increases with the increase of Cu content indicating that the Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst has the most isolated Cu2+ species content, which is in line with H2-TPR results. Additionally, the quantity of CuO species and Cu+ also increases separately with increasing the Cu loading from 1.53 to 3.51 wt.%. However, after hydrothermal aging treatment, the total amount of isolated Cu2+ species decreases, and the amount of CuO increases due to the aggregation of isolated Cu2+ to CuO species [30]. For example, the total quantity of isolated Cu2+ species in Cu1.53-SAPO-18, Cu2.49-SAPO-18 and Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst decreases from 90, 182, and 260 μmol/g to 74, 154, and 174 μmol/g, while the amount of CuO species increases from 20, 73, and 127 μmol/g to 22, 78, and 151 μmol/g, respectively. Such decrease in Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst is more obvious than other catalysts. 3.1.3 NH3-SCR performance As depicted in Fig. 3 , the NO conversions over H-SAPO-18, fresh and aged Cuy-SAPO-18 catalysts in the temperature range of 200–575 ℃ are tested. The H-SAPO-18 does not have any NH3-SCR activity during the whole temperature range. In contrast, all Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts exhibit improved NH3-SCR performance, demonstrating that the introduction of Cu species could provide active center for NH3-SCR reaction. In addition, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with various Cu loadings present different deNOx activities which are caused by the distinct number of isolated Cu2+ ions and CuO species. As proved in many literatures [11,31–33] that isolated Cu2+ ions are active site for NH3-SCR reaction over Cu-zeolite catalysts, however, the CuO species promote NH3 oxidation at high temperature [34,35]. According to Table 2, the total quantity of isolated Cu2+ ions and CuO species in fresh Cuy-SAPO-18 catalysts increases with the rise in Cu content, respectively. Thus, lacking sufficient active isolated Cu2+ ions is a main factor for the inferior catalytic activity of the Cu1.53-SAPO-18 catalyst. Furthermore, Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst shows marginally higher low-temperature (200–300 ℃) NO conversion than Cu2.49-SAPO-18 due to the largest presence of isolated Cu2+ ions. But, the NO conversion over Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst drops significantly because CuO contributes to the oxidation of NH3 and decreases the NH3-SCR performance at high temperature (400–575 ℃). The Cu2.49-SAPO-18 catalyst with suitable isolated Cu2+ ions and CuO species content exhibit excellent NH3-SCR performance during the whole temperature. After hydrothermal treatment at 750 °C, the NH3-SCR performance of Cu1.53-SAPO-18 and Cu2.49-SAPO-18 catalyst decreases slightly due to the less decrease of isolated Cu2+ ions. However, a significant decline of NH3-SCR performance is observed over aged Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst. Because the large presence of CuO species in aged Cu3.51-SAPO-18 catalyst causes some damage to its framework [15,30]. Finally, the Cu2.49-SAPO-18 catalyst exhibits the best deNOx activity after hydrothermal treatment due to the sufficient isolated Cu2+ ions content and relatively low CuO species. From all above results, the Cu2.49-SAPO-18 catalyst shows excellent NH3-SCR activity during the whole temperature and high hydrothermal stability. And, it could be concluded that an appropriate Cu content is beneficial for the NH3-SCR reaction. Thus, copper loading of ca. 2.49 wt.% was chosen for further study. 3.1.4 The NH3-SCR kinetic measurements at low temperature According to the NH3-SCR performance over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts, it can be concluded that the Cu loading influence the deNOx activities. Thus, the NH3-SCR kinetic tests at low temperature are measured to further explore the effect of Cu loading on NH3-SCR reaction mechanism. As plotted in Fig. 4 , the low-temperature NO conversion rates of the three catalysts increases with increasing the Cu loading, which is in accordance with the SCR performance in Fig. 3. Additionally, the three parallel lines demonstrate that the three Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts exhibit similar apparent activation energy (Ea) values of NH3-SCR reactions, suggesting that Cu loading does not affect the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism at low temperature [14]. And the NO conversion rates seem to be affected by the amount of isolated Cu2+ ions. 3.2 Effect of silicon content 3.2.1 The structural properties The XRD patterns in Fig. 5 a show that Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts have similar AEI structure with all H-SAPO-18 supports (Fig. S2). The diffraction peaks intensity of the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts increase with increasing the Si content from 0.084 to 0.173 due to the decrease in crystal defects of Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with higher Si content [36]. But with further increasing the Si content to 0.204, the peak intensity drops, and it might be interpreted by the fact that the large presence of Si island limits the deviation of the TOT (T stands for Al, Si, or P atoms placing in the center of the tetrahedron) band length and angle [37]. It is worth mentioning that the BET and micropore volume results (Table S1) are in accord with XRD results. Meanwhile, the BET surface area of all fresh Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts is between 380 and 480 m2/g, which is conducive to the dispersion of Cu species during impregnation process. And there are no diffraction peaks related to CuO species in XRD profiles, revealing that the copper species is well dispersed or it is too small to be detected. Furthermore, Fig. 5b shows the effect of hydrothermal treatment on the XRD patterns of the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. The XRD peaks intensity of Cu-SAPO-18 drops significantly after hydrothermal aging treatment. And a tridimite (SiO2) dense phase appears at 21.3° in the aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalyst. However, SiO2 phase is hardly detected on the aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) catalyst. This is in good agreement with the BET surface area and micropore volume results. Compared to the fresh catalysts, the BET surface area of aged Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts decreases by 76%, 71%, 52% and 56%, respectively, and the micropore volume decreases by 74%, 70%, 57% and 59%, respectively, with increasing the Si content from 0.084 to 0.204. These results indicate that hydrothermal treatment does some damage to structure of catalysts, and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalysts suffer more severe structural damage during hydrothermal treatment. Meanwhile, the decreased degree of BET surface area and micropore volume of the aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst is less than other catalysts, which illustrates that Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst exhibits better hydrothermal stability than others. 3.2.2 29Si MAS NMR In order to investigate the various Si coordination structures in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts induced by the Si content. The 29Si NMR was carried out for fresh Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. As shown in Fig. 6 , the four Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts all possess five peaks, and they all have an obvious peak at 111.2 ppm, which is ascribed to Si (0OAl) coordination structure in Si islands [23]. The other four peaks at 90.3, 94.5, 99.7, and 105.9 ppm are assigned to Si (4OAl), Si (3OAl), Si (2OAl), Si (1OAl) coordination structure, respectively [38]. The Si (4OAl) structure implies that silicon substitutes via the mechanism I (Si substitutes for P), which will generate the acid sites. And the presence of Si (nOAl, n = 0–3) coordination structure illustrates that silicon substitutes via the mechanism II (Si replaces P and Al), which will result in the formation of Si islands [23,39]. Table 3 lists the fraction of distinct Si coordination structure over fresh Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts. The proportion of Si (4OAl) structure decreases while the percentage of Si (0OAl) structure increases with the increase of Si content. The results demonstrate that the percentage of silicon substituting via the mechanism II will rise with the increase of Si content [23]. Besides, the proportion of Si (xOAl) (x = 1–3) structure in Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts is 34.6%, 48.8%, 49.9% and 41.2%, respectively. It trends to firstly increases and then decreases as the Si content increases. It is well known that Si (0OAl) structure can’t generate acid sites and Si (xOAl) (x = 1–4) structures generate various acid strength. Thus, the formation of different Si coordination structures will affect the number of acid sites of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts and the acid strength of Cu-SAPO-18 supports. 3.2.3 NH3-TPD NH3-TPD is usually used to confirm the strength and number of acid sites in zeolite. Fig. 7 illustrates the NH3-TPD profiles of H-SAPO-18 zeolites, fresh and aged Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. The NH3 desorption peak of H-SAPO-18 zeolites can be divided into three peaks (A, B and C) after deconvolution. The peak A at ca.150 ℃ is assigned to weak acid sites originating from surface free hydroxyl groups due to the structure defect [40]. The peak B appears at 170–200 ℃ representing the adsorbed NH3 molecules at moderate structural Brønsted acid sites [20]. The peak C at 320–350 ℃ could be ascribed to the adsorbed NH3 molecules at strong structural Brønsted acid sites (SiOHAl) [16,37]. In addition, the introduction of Cu into the H-SAPO-18 supports change the acid assignment of peak B and peak C compared to the supports. The peak B intensity of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts significantly increases due to NH3 adsorbed on moderate structural Brønsted acid sites and weak Lewis acid sites created by Cu2+ species [41]. The desorption temperature of peak C of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts shifts to a higher temperature due to the formation of new Lewis acid sites related to Cu species. Thus, the peak C of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts is assigned to the adsorbed NH3 both at strong Brønsted acid sites and strong Lewis acid sites [20,21]. Table 4 shows the NH3 adsorption amount on acid sites calculated from the NH3-TPD result, it can be clearly seen that the strong acid sites over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts decrease with respect to the support due to isolated Cu2+ ions substituting the proton of H-SAPO-18 supports. However, the total acid sites over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts are more than H-SAPO-18 supports, which can be interpreted by the fact that NH3 can be adsorbed on Cu2+ species, resulting in the increase of total NH3 amount [41]. For H-SAPO-18 supports, the different Si coordination structures decide the acid strength of the SAPOs, and their acidity presents the order as follows [21,42]: Si (1OAl) > Si (2OAl) > Si (3OAl) > Si (4OAl) > Si (0OAl). Chen et.al [23] reported that the acid sites over SAPO-18 increased with the rise in Si content, but this increase will reach a maximum. In our research, as listed in Table 4, an increase in the acid sites over H-SAPO-18 supports with the Si content increasing from 0.084 to 0.173 followed by a decrease in acid sites with further increase in the silicon content. Therefore, H-SAPO-18 (0.173) support has the most acid sites among all the zeolites. The introduction of Cu affects the acid sites distribution, the variation tendency of the entire acid sites content over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts is analogous to that over H-SAPO-18 supports. The whole acid sites amount over Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst is maximum. Fig. 7c presents that the quantity of total acid sites of aged Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts distinctly drops compared with fresh catalysts, it seems that hydrothermal treatment has a negative impact on the number of acid sites, which is due to the collapse of catalyst structure to some extent and loss of isolated Cu2+ ions during hydrothermal treatment. What’s more, Table 4 presents that the amount of acid sites decreases by 52%, 53%, 41%, 47%, respectively, after hydrothermal treatment with increasing the Si content from 0.084 to 0.204. Such decrease in aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst is less significant than other catalysts, suggesting that the acid sites in the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst are less affected than that in other catalysts during the hydrothermal treatment. 3.2.4 H2-TPR Fig. 8 shows the H2-TPR curves of fresh and aged Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts. For the fresh Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts, as depicted in Section 3.1.2, the H2-TPR curves can be also divided into five peaks after deconvolution, denoted as A, B, C, D and E. The peak A, and C can be attributed to the reduction of isolated Cu2+ ions. The peak B is due to the reduction of CuO. The peak D and E can be assigned to the reduction of less stable Cu+ and high stable Cu+ species, respectively, where the reduction of Cu+ species contains the initial Cu+ species existing in zeolites and Cu+ species reduced by isolated Cu2+ ions. As shown in Table 2, it can be seen that the number of total isolated Cu2+ species in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts increases with the increase of silicon content from 0.084 to 0.173, then drops for higher Si content of 0.204, which might be due to the fact that the isolated Cu2+ ions content of Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst is related to the number of acid sites [20]. After hydrothermal treatment at 750 ℃, with increasing the Si content from 0.084 to 0.204, the total quantity of isolated Cu2+ species decreases from 137, 169, 205 and 184 μmol/g, to 80, 93, 147 and 111 μmol/g, respectively. Meanwhile, the amount of CuO and Cu+ species increases due to the transformation of isolated Cu2+ species during the hydrothermal treatment, and the CuO species might destroy the framework of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. It is worth noting that the amount of isolated Cu2+ species in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts is reduced by 42%, 45%, 28%, and 40% with the increase of Si content after hydrothermal aging, respectively. The results indicate the isolated Cu2+ species in Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst is more stable than other catalysts. 3.2.5 EPR EPR is an effective measurement to quantitatively identify the amount of isolated Cu2+ ions because other Cu species (CuO, Cu+, etc.) don’t generate EPR signal [33]. Fig. 9 exhibits the EPR spectra of fresh and aged Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts and there are four weak peaks and one vertical sharp axisymmetric peak with the value of g// = 2.39 mT, A// = 13.17 mT and g⊥ = 2.06 mT. Meanwhile, the semi-quantitative results by double integration of the EPR spectroscopy are plotted in Fig. S3, although the fresh Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts have similar Cu loadings, the EPR integral area of fresh Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts increases, with the increase of Si content from 0.084 to 0173, and then decreases with further increasing the Si content. It means that Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst has the most total isolated Cu2+ species, which is in accordance with the H2-TPR results. What’s more, the decrease in EPR integral area of aged Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts suggests that the quantity of isolated Cu2+ species drops. And, the decreased degree of isolated Cu2+ species in aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst is less than other catalysts, demonstrating the more robust stability of isolated Cu2+ species in Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst. 3.2.6 NH3-SCR performance The catalytic activities of the fresh and aged Cu-SAPO-18 (x) catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 10 as a function of temperature. The NH3-SCR performance of the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts improves with increasing silicon content from 0.084 to 0.173 and then declines for the highest silicon content of 0.204. The Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst manifests the excellent NH3-SCR activity during the entire temperature range, and the NO conversion is higher than 91% in the temperature range of 250 ℃–525 ℃. However, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) catalyst performs an inferior NO conversion among all the catalysts. In addition, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) also have high activities from 275 ℃ to 500 ℃ (NO conversion >89%). As depicted in Fig. 10b, after hydrothermal aging at 750 ℃, the NH3-SCR activity of Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalyst decreases sharply during the whole temperature range, and the highest NO conversion is no more than 70% and 75%, respectively. The NO conversion reduces over aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) catalyst, and the optimum NO conversion decreases from 94% to 84% after hydrothermal treatment. Nevertheless, the NH3-SCR activity over aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst decreases slightly, and the NO conversion could reach above 89% in the range of 275–475 ℃. The above results indicate that Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) is more robust than other catalysts during the hydrothermal treatment. 3.2.7 The effect of Si content on NH3-SCR performance The evidences all above point to the fact that the NH3-SCR activities and hydrothermal stability of the catalysts are related to silicon content, which can be attributed to the following reasons. Firstly, Table 3 shows the different Si coordination structures and their contents in the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. It is well known that the acid sites in SAPO molecular sieves are created by the substitution of P atoms with Si atoms. Thus, the acid sites content will rise with the increase of Si content due to the substitution of more Si atoms for P atoms. Simultaneously, Si atoms are more prone to replace the P and Al atoms with increasing the Si content, which generate more neutral Si(0OAl) structure. And based on NH3-TPD results, the quantity of acid sites in Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts increases with increasing the Si content from 0.084 to 0.173. However, with further increasing the Si content to 0.204, the quantity of acid sites drops due to the largest present of neutral Si(0OAl) structure, which can’t generate acid sites. Meanwhile Table 4 presents the number of moderate and strong Brønsted acid sites in H-SAPO-18 supports shows the following sequence: H-SAPO-18 (0.173) > H-SAPO-18 (0.204) > H-SAPO-18 (0.118) > H-SAPO-18 (0.084). The reason is that Si (nOAl, n = 1–3) structures firstly increase then decrease with the increase of Si content. What’s more, the Brønsted acid sites play positive role in NH3-SCR reaction, by providing NH3 species to the copper sites for reacting with NOx to form N2 at high temperature [16]. For example, the H-SAPO-18 (0.173) and H-SAPO-18 (0.084) support have the most number of moderate and strong Brønsted acid sites and the least number of moderate and strong Brønsted acid sites, respectively. When the introduction of Cu into the H-SAPO-18 support, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst exhibits the highest deNOx activity, but the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) catalyst performs the lowest deNOx activity. Moreover, it has been proved that the loading of Cu species in H-SAPO-18 supports can generate active site for NH3-SCR reaction in above result. Indeed, it is well accepted that isolated Cu2+ species are active sites for NH3-SCR reaction. Interestingly, when the Cu incorporates into the H-SAPO-18 supports, the strong Brønsted acid sites content decreases, revealing that Cu2+ ions are located at the strong Brønsted acid sites. This phenomenon might be ascribed to the fact that Cu2+ ions can only exchange with the acid site created by the Si substitution [20].Therefore, the H-SAPO-18 supports with more number of strong Brønsted acid sites is beneficial to the increase of Cu2+ ions. Meanwhile, the excess Cu2+ ions may transform to CuO during the calcination, which could inhibit the NH3-SCR activity at high temperature. Besides, the CuO species could lead to the structural collapse of Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst during the hydrothermal treatment. Additionally, Table 4 shows that the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with lower number of acid sites has a higher content of Cu+ species. Although the Cu+ ions can improve the low-temperature NH3-SCR performance, a slight increase in Cu+ species content could not lead to high NH3-SCR performance due to the abundant Cu+ species already existing in four Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts [43,44]. Finally, according to the above results, Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst with appropriate Si content possesses the most number of moderate and strong acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions, and the low number of CuO species, which can be responsible for the excellent catalytic activity. To further demonstrate the conclusions above, the kinetics studies were performed over fresh Cu-SAPO-18(x) catalysts at low temperature. As shown in Fig. 11 , the four Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts present identical Ea, implying the acid sites content does not affect the NH3-SCR reaction mechanisms over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts. Meanwhile, the NO reaction rates are consistent with the NH3-SCR performance, which indicates that the large number of moderate and strong acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions in Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst is responsible for outstanding NH3-SCR performance. What’s more, after hydrothermal treatment at 750 ℃, the decline in NO conversion over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with various Si content is different. For example, the deNOx activities of aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084), Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) catalyst decreases significantly, while NO conversion over aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst retains almost intact. The XRD, N2 adsorption-desorption, H2-TPR and EPR results suggest that the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst suffers less damage in structure and less decrease in the number of isolated Cu2+ species. The reason is that the largest number of strong acid sites in Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst is conducive to stabilizing the isolated Cu2+ species during hydrothermal aging [20,45]. Thus, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst exhibits better hydrothermal stability than other catalysts. Furthermore, the reasons for the inferior hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084), Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118), and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) catalyst could be interpreted as follows. In the case of Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalysts which have low strong acid sites content, the less isolated Cu2+ ions would be located at the acid sites during the process of incipient wetness impregnation. The excess Cu2+ species, which would reside in the framework and channel of catalyst may transform to CuO species during the calcination due to its instability [20,30]. While the large present of CuO species causes damage to the framework of Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalysts during the hydrothermal aging. Besides, the decrease of strong acid sites content is also adverse to the stability of isolated Cu2+ ions. Finally, the aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalysts exhibit low NH3-SCR activities. For the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) catalyst with the highest Si content has the largest number of Si(0OAl) structure, which can’t stabilize the extra-framework Cu2+ species during the hydrothermal treatment, resulting in structural damage to some extent. However, the aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.204) catalyst exhibits higher catalytic activity than the aged Cu-SAPO-18 (0.084) and Cu-SAPO-18 (0.118) catalysts due to the more number of moderate and strong acid sites and isolated Cu2+ species. In conclusion, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with suitable Si content is propitious to the preservation of zeolitic structure, acid sites, and isolated Cu2+ species, which further makes positive contribution to hydrothermal stability of catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this study, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with various Cu content or Si content were reported to understand the relationship among the nature of Cu species, acid sites and NH3-SCR performance before and after hydrothermal aging treatment. The results show that with the increase of Cu loading from 1.53 to 3.51 wt.%, the amount of isolated Cu2+ species and CuO species increases, respectively. And the Cu2.49-SAPO-18 catalyst performs excellent NH3-SCR performance during the whole temperature and good hydrothermal stability. Furthermore, for Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst, the acid sites content is decided by the Si content, which further affects the number of isolated Cu2+ species. And the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with a large number of acid sites and isolated Cu2+ species is propitious to NH3-SCR activity. Additionally, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with low acid sites content suffers more severe loss of isolated Cu2+ species during hydrothermal treatment, resulting in inferior hydrothermal stability. And the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with the highest Si content possesses the most number of Si(0OAl) structure, which is prone to lead to structural damage during hydrothermal treatment. Finally, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with appropriate Si content exhibits better NH3-SCR performance and hydrothermal stability, which makes it a promising candidate in diesel exhaust purification. coredata.dc:description: The effect of Cu loading and Si content on catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts prepared by incipient wetness impregnation method was investigated in ammonia selective catalytic reduction (NH3-SCR) reaction. The Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst with Cu loading of 2.49 wt.% shows superior NH3-SCR performance and hydrothermal stability due to the presence of more isolated Cu2+ species and the less amount of CuO species. What’s more, the Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts with different Si content exhibit distinct NH3-SCR performance, though they contain similar Cu loading. The NH3-TPD, H2-TPR and EPR results indicate that the number of acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions over Cu-SAPO-18 catalysts rises with increasing Si content from 0.084 to 0.173, but decreases with the highest Si content of 0.204. Consequently, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst shows the best NH3-SCR performance. After hydrothermal treatment, the Cu-SAPO-18 (0.173) catalyst exhibits excellent NO reduction efficiency which attributes to its stable framework and the most amount of acid sites and isolated Cu2+ ions. Additionally, the NH3-SCR kinetic analysis over Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst was also performed and suggesting that Cu loading and Si content do not influence the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of copper loading and silicon content on catalytic activity and hydrothermal stability of Cu-SAPO-18 catalyst for NH3-SCR
